title: About
text:
I am a spatial data analyst interested in urban systems, remote sensing, spatial epidemiology, and data development. Currently, I work in First Nations Health with the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW).
I am based in London, UK.
e: joepost51@gmail.com

title: GIS Portfolio
text:
Who am I? I am a spatial data analyst interested in urban systems, remote sensing, spatial epidemiology, and data development. Currently, I work in First Nations Health with the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare (AIHW). I am based in London, UK.
What is this? This is a GIS portfolio of my previous work, with examples of projects completed throughout professional work and as part of my MSc in Urban Spatial Science, at UCL Bartlett. I’ve designed this website to accompany my application to McGregor Coxall’s Biourbanism Lab.
Please navigate through the tabs to view static work, interactive apps, my resume, and contact details for further information.
This website has been authored in reproducible markdown using Quarto open-source software and RStudio, published via Github Pages.

title: Shiny Apps
text:
Blue plaque density in London: an interactive map
This shiny app presents an interactive map built in R and leaflet, that calculates the blue plaque density by borough in London. It was developed as part of the course CASA0005 GIS.

title: Work
text:
The figures below comprise part of my MSc dissertation, using remote sensing and spatial disaggregation to estimate agricultural dependence in the population at a small area scale. This project involved 2 stages, (1) testing proof-of-concept on a subregion, the state of Karnataka in Western India, and (2) scaling up the analytical process to produce estimates for the whole of India.
Figures a–c are visualisations of the input datasets used in the population disaggregation model. Figure d shows the output of the model.



Karnataka sub-region maps


Figures e and f provide a reference for the study region, Karnataka and India.



India reference maps

title: Work
section: Extended urbanisation in the Gauteng City Region
text:
Extended urbanisation in the Gauteng City Region

The Gauteng City-Region comprises the combined metropolis of Johannesburg, Pretoria, and surrounds, and forms the largest urban agglomeration in South Africa. In this project, I worked with the Gauteng City Region Observatory to explore the spatial dimensions emerging from Quality of Life survey data, with a specific focus on peripheral settlements. The work was published as part of the GCRO’s ‘Map of the Month Series’, and the full report can be found here.
The project investigated dimensions of gendered travel across the region, commuting distance, and sense of belonging. This work was completed as part of a field course organised by the UCL Urban Lab.



GCRO Map of the month
